On Fri, 16 Jul 2004 22:57:38 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> 1) Tic Tac Toe -  I created a new player based on the 'Best' player
> described in Derek and Philips paper (originally from elsewhere I
> believe). I initially modified the strategy by making it randomly select
> from the set of available moves at any given point in a game. 
<snip>
> What this does is provide a more varied range of play, that hopefully
> will help evolve more robust players. 

We thought about doing a probability distribution of suggested moves. 
It's a good idea, and I'll be interested to see how it works out.

As for the range of play and robustness of evolved players, it's
probably worth noting that all of our hand-coded players have an
element of randomness (especially RAND!).

This makes the evaluation noisier, but in general we've found that it
prevents overfitting and leads to more robust players.  I think adding
randomness to pretty much any domain is important in order to
compensate for noise in the domain and produce more robust
controllers/players/etc.

> This extra player hasn't greatly improved the evolved networks so far,
> although some experimenting with the above startegy is still required.

Keep us posted.

On that note, we've continued to tinker with Tic-Tac-Toe as we've
implemented our active vision system.

One thing we've noticed is that some of the activation function
approximations (e.g., the EvSail sigmoid) tend to increase speed, but
produce less-than-desirable results.  In both XOR and TTT, the
approximated activation functions lead to signficantly reduced
performance.  I'd be interested to know if anyone else has done such
comparisons.

It looks like the smoothness of the curve in the activation function
is really quite important, at least in the domains we've worked in.

> 2) Phased searching - The current plan then is to implement the 'phased
> search' technique discussed on this groups a while ago, and to see if it
> is able evolve better players. Before I do this though I want to
> implement a more simple problem domain, one that is fast to evaluate so
> that experiments can be run a lot faster....

Again, keep us up to date.

> 3)OCR - Optical Character Recognition. 

We're going to be doing OCR as well. :)  We'll be using an active
vision/roving eye approach.

We hope to be able to post some results in a few weeks.

Derek
